Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract:

In high-energy physics, the structure of matter is explored by accelerating and colliding elementary particles like electrons and protons. In condensed matter physics, the fundamental excitations are called quasi-particles. The most familiar quasi-particles are electrons and holes in semiconductors, which can be created for example in a solar photovoltaic cell - by light with a sufficiently short wavelength. In this project, electrons and holes will be created by a weak near-infrared laser with a wavelength slightly longer than is visible to the human eye, and will be made to accelerate and then recollide with one another by a very strong electric field oscillating nearly 1 trillion times per second (1 Terahertz). The recollision process will be studied by analyzing the spectrum (which wavelengths are present) in the transmitted near-infrared light. This spectrum has been shown to contain up to 18 separate nearinfrared wavelengths, or sidebands, in addition to the wavelength of the near-infrared laser that creates electron-hole pairs. This research will elucidate how much quasiparticles can be accelerated without being disturbed by defects or the motion of atoms in their host material. The proposed research may lead to faster and more energy efficient optical communications and internet, and improved optical clocks that are necessary in the global positioning system. This project will support the training of two Ph. D. students, who will learn a variety of skills that are critical to preserving U. S. competitiveness in the high-technology sector.

Technical abstract:

High-order sideband generation, a new phenomenon in the interaction of light with matter, was recently discovered in the PI's research group. A relatively weak, continuous-wave near-infrared (NIR) laser at frequency ~350 THz, and an intense laser at frequency ~0.5 THz are incident on a thin film of semiconductor. A comb of equally-spaced sidebands is emitted, with sharp lines at sideband frequency = NIR frequency + 2n THz frequency, where n is an integer. Combs with up to 14 sidebands (order up to 2*14=28) above NIR frequency have been observed. The high-order sidebands can be understood in terms of a semiclassical model similar to one that was first introduced to explain high-order harmonic generation, an analogous phenomenon that occurs for atoms in intense laser fields. In high-order-sideband generation (HSG), the NIR laser creates excitons, bound electron-hole pairs. The strong THz field ionizes the excitons, and accelerates the resulting electron and hole into a large-amplitude oscillation. When the electron and hole recollide, the excess kinetic energy is carried off in sidebands above the NIR frequency. This project will explore the onset of high-order sideband generation, whether there is a fundamental limit on the number of observable sidebands, whether the shape of the sideband spectrum can be controlled, and whether, in the case of a circularly-polarized terahertz field, the polarization of the near-ir radiation is rotated. By exploring the limits of HSG, the proposed research will elucidate potential applications of HSG to electro-optic technologies ranging from optical communications to optical clocks. This project will support the training of two Ph.D. students, who will learn a variety of skills including near-ir and terahertz optics, cryogenics, electronics, computer programming, and mechanical and optomechanical design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamical birefringence:  electron-hole recollisions as probes of Berry curvature.

In 1984, mathematician Michael Berry discovered a surprising new feature of quantum mechanics, which can be illustrated by the following thought experiment.  Imagine a compass that is so small that its state is governed by the laws of quantum mechanics, and that it is on a flat table.  Now pick up the compass, slowly tilt the compass away from horizontal, and then put it back on the flat table in the exact same place.   Even though the compass is back in exactly the same place, its quantum mechanical state, described by a wave function, may be different—the new wave function will in general be the original wavefunction multiplied by a phase that is now called a Berry phase.  The concepts of Berry phase and Berry curvature are central to understanding new and exotic phases of condensed matter that have distinct topological properties.  In addition to their intrinsic scientific interest, some of these exotic phases of condensed matter are promising candidates for a type of quantum computer that is immune to the effects of decoherence, which in general destroys quantum mechanical phases.

In spite of its importance, at the present time, there exist no good methods for measuring Berry curvature.  Supported by this NSF grant, a collaboration involving UCSB, Princeton, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the Naval Research Lab made a surprising discovery--that electron-hole recollisions, which are described in some detail in the Project Outcomes report for NSF-DMR 1006603, can be used to probe Berry curvature, opening the door to directly measuring this important quantity.  The ability to directly measure Berry curvature in a wide range of materials would enable engineering materials with desired topological properties.

The discovery began with major improvements to the PI’s group’s ability to measure electron-hole recollisions via the phenomenon of high-order sideband generation, in which a monochromatic near-ir laser beam, after transmission through a semiconductor driven by a strong terahertz-frequency electric field, becomes decorated with a rainbow-like spectrum of new frequencies, separated from one another and the near-ir laser line by twice the terahertz frequency.  As a result of these improvements, sidebands separated from the near-ir laser line by up to 90 times the terahertz frequency were observed.  Above a sufficiently high order, the sidebands were significantly stronger if the electric field of the near-ir laser was polarized perpendicular to the terahertz field than if the two fields were parallel, indicating that the terahertz-driven semiconductor was behaving in some ways like the polarizing films used to cut down glare in polarizing sunglasses, even though the semiconductor in the absence of terahertz radiation has no polarizing properties.  We call this phenomenon dynamical birefringence.  A new theory was developed to understand the experimental observations, and the inescapable conclusion was that the polarizing properties of the terahertz-driven semiconductor arise because the charge carriers that were injected by the near ir laser experienced the Berry curvature of the semiconductor as they were accelerated and smashed back together by the strong terahertz field.  The PI’s group is currently working to use dynamical birefringence to experimentally reconstruct the Berry curvature in a solid for the first time.

There may also be direct technological applications of high-order sideband generation in the areas of fiber-optic communications, compact spectrometers for sensing trace gases that could be deployed on cell-phone-like platforms, and compact optical atomic clocks that could be used for inertial navigation.
